title: 106_hr3209
content:
SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE. Congress finds that decommissioned firearms once used by law enforcement agencies have been involved in over 3,000 crimes in the past 9 years, including 293 homicides, 301 assaults, and 279 drug-related crimes. Additionally, white supremacist Buford Furrow used a Glock pistol sold by a law enforcement agency in Washington to commit a shooting at a Jewish community center in Los Angeles. The Act aims to reduce the circulation of decommissioned firearms used in crimes by preventing their transfer to individuals. Law enforcement agencies in various states have started destroying these firearms to curb their misuse. The Act aims to reduce the circulation of decommissioned firearms used in crimes by preventing their transfer to individuals. Law enforcement agencies in various states have started destroying these firearms to curb their misuse. SEC. 3. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Attorney General may grant funds to States or local governments to purchase new firearms and destroy decommissioned firearms. Eligibility requires a law or policy to prevent transferring decommissioned firearms to individuals, allowing transfer only to other law enforcement agencies. The Attorney General may grant funds to States or local governments to purchase new firearms and destroy decommissioned firearms. A State or local government receiving a grant must use it only to buy new firearms and not transfer decommissioned firearms to individuals, allowing transfer only to other law enforcement agencies. To apply for a grant under this Act, the chief executive of a State or unit of local government must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information. Regulations for the grants are also outlined. The Attorney General will establish regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment for grant applications. States and local governments must report on Act implementation within 2 years of receiving funds. Budget assurances for future firearm purchases by law enforcement are required. SEC. 7. DEFINITION.

    The term "firearm" is defined as in section 921(a)(3) of title 18, United States Code. A "decommissioned firearm" is one no longer used by law enforcement or needed for evidentiary purposes. The term "person" is defined as in section 1 of title 1 of the United States Code.

SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

    $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005 to carry out this Act.
